mn24:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
mn24:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
mn24:1.2.comm: The Bamboo Grove was a major monastery near Rājagaha. According to Kd 1:22.16.1, it was offered by King Bimbisāra as the very first monastery dedicated to the Saṅgha.

mn24:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā jātibhūmakā bhikkhū jātibhūmiyaṃ vassaṃvuṭṭhā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:
mn24:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants who had completed the rainy season residence in their native land went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:
mn24:2.1.comm: The commentary says jātibhūmi means the Buddha’s native land, but the word occurs at AN 6.54, Pvr 14:2.1, Ja 537:26.1, and Ja 546:43.1, where it always means “one’s native land”. Given that Puṇṇa, the most famous teacher of their land, was unknown by Sāriputta, it seems likely that it was somewhat remote. One of the Chinese parallels (MA 9) describes him as of light skin and prominent nose, a description that might befit someone from the north-west of India.

mn24:2.2.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhikkhave, jātibhūmiyaṃ jātibhūmakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ evaṃ sambhāvito:
mn24:2.2.eng: “In your native land, mendicants, which of the native mendicants is esteemed in this way:

mn24:2.3.pli: ‘attanā ca appiccho appicchakathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca santuṭṭho santuṭṭhikathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca pavivitto pavivekakathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca asaṃsaṭṭho asaṃsaggakathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca āraddhavīriyo vīriyārambhakathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca sīlasampanno sīlasampadākathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca samādhisampanno samādhisampadākathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca paññāsampanno paññāsampadākathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca vimuttisampanno vimuttisampadākathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno vimuttiñāṇadassanasampadākathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, ovādako viññāpako sandassako samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnan’”ti?
mn24:2.3.eng: ‘Personally having few wishes, they speak to the mendicants on having few wishes. Personally having contentment, seclusion, aloofness, energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom, they speak to the mendicants on all these things. They’re an adviser and counselor, one who educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires their spiritual companions.’”

mn24:2.4.pli: “Puṇṇo nāma, bhante, āyasmā mantāṇiputto jātibhūmiyaṃ jātibhūmakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ evaṃ sambhāvito:
mn24:2.4.eng: “Puṇṇa son of Mantāṇī, sir, is esteemed in this way in our native land.”
mn24:2.4.comm: Although said to be the foremost Dhamma speaker (AN 1.196:1.1, see SN 14.15:2.14), few of his teachings are recorded. At SN 22.83, Ānanda attributes his initial breakthrough to Puṇṇa, while a single verse is attributed to him at Thag 1.4. | Puṇṇa was evidently from the same maternal clan as Aṅgulimāla (MN 86:12.12). This name does not seem to occur in Sanskrit texts, but Mahāvastu 3.377 spells it as Maitrāyaṇī, a name shared with the Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā, the oldest ritual text of the Black Yajurveda.

mn24:2.5.pli: ‘attanā ca appiccho appicchakathañca bhikkhūnaṃ kattā, attanā ca santuṭṭho …pe… ovādako viññāpako sandassako samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnan’”ti.

mn24:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti.
mn24:3.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting not far from the Buddha.

mn24:3.3.pli: “lābhā āyasmato puṇṇassa mantāṇiputtassa, suladdhalābhā āyasmato puṇṇassa mantāṇiputtassa,
mn24:3.3.eng: “Puṇṇa son of Mantāṇī is fortunate, so very fortunate,

mn24:3.4.pli: yassa viññū sabrahmacārī satthu sammukhā anumassa anumassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, tañca satthā abbhanumodati.
mn24:3.4.eng: in that his sensible spiritual companions praise him point by point in the presence of the Teacher, and that the Teacher seconds that appreciation.

mn24:3.5.pli: Appeva nāma mayampi kadāci karahaci āyasmatā puṇṇena mantāṇiputtena saddhiṃ samāgaccheyyāma, appeva nāma siyā kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti.
mn24:3.5.eng: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet Venerable Puṇṇa, and we can have a discussion.”

mn24:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahe yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
mn24:4.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Rājagaha as long as he pleased, he set out for Sāvatthī.

mn24:4.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena sāvatthi tadavasari.
mn24:4.2.eng: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sāvatthī,

mn24:4.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn24:4.3.eng: where he stayed in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn24:4.4.pli: Assosi kho āyasmā puṇṇo mantāṇiputto: “bhagavā kira sāvatthiṃ anuppatto; sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme”ti.
mn24:4.4.eng: Puṇṇa heard that the Buddha had arrived at Sāvatthī.

mn24:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇo mantāṇiputto senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
mn24:5.1.eng: Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sāvatthī.

mn24:5.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena sāvatthi jetavanaṃ anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn24:5.2.eng: Eventually he came to Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

mn24:5.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
mn24:5.3.eng: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.

mn24:5.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇo mantāṇiputto bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena andhavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
mn24:5.4.eng: Then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, Puṇṇa got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation.

mn24:6.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn24:6.1.eng: Then a certain mendicant went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and said to him,

mn24:6.2.pli: “yassa kho tvaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, puṇṇassa nāma bhikkhuno mantāṇiputtassa abhiṇhaṃ kittayamāno ahosi, so bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena andhavanaṃ tena pakkanto divāvihārāyā”ti.
mn24:6.2.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, the mendicant named Puṇṇa, of whom you have often spoken so highly, after being inspired by a talk of the Buddha’s, left for the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation.”

mn24:7.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto taramānarūpo nisīdanaṃ ādāya āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi sīsānulokī.
mn24:7.1.eng: Sāriputta quickly grabbed his sitting cloth and followed behind Puṇṇa, keeping sight of his head.
mn24:7.1.comm: While similar actions are found elsewhere, they are not said to be done “quickly” (taramānarūpo). Sāriputta’s urgency here reinforces the impression that Puṇṇa lived somewhere distant and visited the central regions only occasionally.

mn24:7.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇo mantāṇiputto andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
mn24:7.2.eng: Puṇṇa plunged deep into the Dark Forest and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

mn24:7.3.pli: Āyasmāpi kho sāriputto andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.

mn24:8.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā puṇṇo mantāṇiputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā puṇṇena mantāṇiputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn24:8.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Puṇṇa, and exchanged greetings with him.

mn24:8.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn24:8.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Puṇṇa:
mn24:8.2.comm: The following seven “purifications” became one of the primary textual sources for the commentarial system of “insight knowledges” (vipassanañāṇa) that became central to later Theravada meditation. It would be a mistake, however, to interpret this sutta in light of the insight knowledges, which were developed over a thousand years.

mn24:9.1.eng: “Reverend, is our spiritual life lived under the Buddha?”
mn24:9.1.comm: Puṇṇa was a stranger, so Sāriputta begins by establishing common ground before asking a series of questions to which he expects a negative answer.

mn24:9.3.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
mn24:9.3.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of ethics?”
mn24:9.3.comm: The questions are framed in an unusual paired syntax: kiṁ nu kho, āvuso alternates with kiṁ panāvuso.

mn24:9.5.eng: “Well, is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of mind?”
mn24:9.5.comm: “Purification of mind” is the development of absorption to abandon the hindrances (AN 4.194:4.1).

mn24:9.7.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, diṭṭhivisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
mn24:9.7.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of view?”
mn24:9.7.comm: “Purified view” is the right view of the stream-enterer who has seen the four noble truths (AN 4.194:5.1) and rejected the fetter of views of a self (sakkāyadiṭṭhi). | Likewise, the five items from here down to “knowledge and vision” all refer to stream-entry. This sutta departs from other early presentations in presenting these as a sequence, whereas normally they are different facets of the experience of stream-entry.

mn24:9.9.eng: “Well, is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification by traversing doubt?”
mn24:9.9.comm: Doubt is one of the fetters overcome by the stream-enterer (eg. MN 64:6.4), since they have the confidence born of direct experience of the four noble truths. | At Ud 5.7 “purification by traversing doubt” is said to be achieved by the practice of jhāna.

mn24:9.11.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
mn24:9.11.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path?”
mn24:9.11.comm: From their own experience, a stream-enterer knows what leads to the goal and what does not, hence they give up the fetter of “misapprehension of precepts and observances”. | For maggāmagga, see the debate between brahmin students at DN 13:3.1, which shows that this term is not unique to Buddhism. There is, however, no evidence that the sequence of purifications is found outside of Buddhism.

mn24:9.13.eng: “Well, is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision of the practice?”
mn24:9.13.comm: A stream-enterer not only understands what the correct path is, they have actually practiced it (SN 55.5:3.3).

mn24:9.15.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, ñāṇadassanavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
mn24:9.15.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision?”
mn24:9.15.comm: This is the vision of the four noble truths at stream-entry (SN 25.1:2.4).

mn24:10.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
mn24:10.1.eng: “When asked each of these questions, you answered, ‘Certainly not.’

mn24:10.2.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso, cittavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.

mn24:10.7.pli: kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, ñāṇadassanavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ āvuso’ti vadesi.

mn24:10.8.eng: Then what exactly is the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha?”

mn24:10.9.eng: “The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.”
mn24:10.9.comm: In other words, for arahantship not stream-entry.

mn24:11.1.eng: “Reverend, is purification of ethics complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping?”

mn24:11.9.eng: purification of knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path …

mn24:11.11.eng: purification of knowledge and vision of the practice …

mn24:11.13.eng: Is purification of knowledge and vision complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping?”

mn24:11.15.eng: “Then is complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping something apart from these things?”

mn24:12.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, sīlavisuddhi anupādāparinibbānan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
mn24:12.1.eng: “When asked each of these questions, you answered, ‘Certainly not.’

mn24:12.2.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso, cittavisuddhi anupādāparinibbānan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.

mn24:12.7.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, ñāṇadassanavisuddhi anupādāparinibbānan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.

mn24:12.8.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso, aññatra imehi dhammehi anupādāparinibbānan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.

mn24:12.9.pli: Yathākathaṃ panāvuso, imassa bhāsitassa attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
mn24:12.9.eng: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”

mn24:13.1.pli: “Sīlavisuddhiñce, āvuso, bhagavā anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya, saupādānaṃyeva samānaṃ anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya.
mn24:13.1.eng: “If the Buddha had declared purification of ethics to be complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping, he would have declared that which has fuel for grasping to be complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.
mn24:13.1.comm: Compare the simile of the raft at MN 22:13.1.

mn24:13.2.pli: Cittavisuddhiñce, āvuso, bhagavā anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya, saupādānaṃyeva samānaṃ anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya.
mn24:13.2.eng: If the Buddha had declared purification of mind …

mn24:13.3.pli: Diṭṭhivisuddhiñce, āvuso, bhagavā anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya, saupādānaṃyeva samānaṃ anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya.

mn24:13.4.pli: Kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhiñce, āvuso, bhagavā anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya, saupādānaṃyeva samānaṃ anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya.

mn24:13.5.pli: Maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhiñce, āvuso, bhagavā anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya, saupādānaṃyeva samānaṃ anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya.
mn24:13.5.eng: purification of knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path …

mn24:13.6.pli: Paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhiñce, āvuso, bhagavā anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya, saupādānaṃyeva samānaṃ anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya.
mn24:13.6.eng: purification of knowledge and vision of the practice …

mn24:13.7.pli: Ñāṇadassanavisuddhiñce, āvuso, bhagavā anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya, saupādānaṃyeva samānaṃ anupādāparinibbānaṃ paññapeyya.
mn24:13.7.eng: If the Buddha had declared purification of knowledge and vision to be complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping, he would have declared that which has fuel for grasping to be complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.

mn24:13.8.pli: Aññatra ce, āvuso, imehi dhammehi anupādāparinibbānaṃ abhavissa, puthujjano parinibbāyeyya.
mn24:13.8.eng: But if complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping was something apart from these things, an ordinary person would become extinguished.
mn24:13.8.comm: That is to say, the goal is not the same as the path, but it cannot be attained without the path.

mn24:13.9.pli: Puthujjano hi, āvuso, aññatra imehi dhammehi.
mn24:13.9.eng: For an ordinary person lacks these things.

mn24:14.1.eng: Well then, reverend, I shall give you a simile.

mn24:14.2.pli: upamāyapidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
mn24:14.2.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

mn24:14.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasantassa sākete kiñcideva accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ uppajjeyya.
mn24:14.3.eng: Suppose that, while staying in Sāvatthī, King Pasenadi of Kosala had some urgent business come up in Sāketa.

mn24:14.4.pli: Tassa antarā ca sāvatthiṃ antarā ca sāketaṃ satta rathavinītāni upaṭṭhapeyyuṃ.
mn24:14.4.eng: Now, between Sāvatthī and Sāketa seven chariots were stationed at the ready for him.
mn24:14.4.comm: Rathavinīta, which lends the sutta its title, is explained by the commentary as “seven chariots with horses at the ready”, where vinīta has its usual sense of “trained, readied”. While the series of chariots forms a relay, the word vinīta does not mean “relay”. The term and the simile are unique to this sutta.

mn24:14.5.pli: Atha kho, āvuso, rājā pasenadi kosalo sāvatthiyā nikkhamitvā antepuradvārā paṭhamaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruheyya, paṭhamena rathavinītena dutiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇeyya, paṭhamaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjeyya dutiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruheyya.
mn24:14.5.eng: Then Pasenadi, exiting Sāvatthī, mounted the first chariot at the ready by the gate of the royal compound. The first chariot at the ready would bring him to the second, where he’d dismount and mount the second chariot.

mn24:14.6.pli: Dutiyena rathavinītena tatiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇeyya, dutiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjeyya, tatiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruheyya.
mn24:14.6.eng: The second chariot at the ready would bring him to the third …

mn24:14.7.pli: Tatiyena rathavinītena catutthaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇeyya, tatiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjeyya, catutthaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruheyya.
mn24:14.7.eng: The third chariot at the ready would bring him to the fourth …

mn24:14.8.pli: Catutthena rathavinītena pañcamaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇeyya, catutthaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjeyya, pañcamaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruheyya.
mn24:14.8.eng: The fourth chariot at the ready would bring him to the fifth …

mn24:14.9.pli: Pañcamena rathavinītena chaṭṭhaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇeyya, pañcamaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjeyya, chaṭṭhaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruheyya.
mn24:14.9.eng: The fifth chariot at the ready would bring him to the sixth …

mn24:14.10.pli: Chaṭṭhena rathavinītena sattamaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇeyya, chaṭṭhaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjeyya, sattamaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruheyya.
mn24:14.10.eng: The sixth chariot at the ready would bring him to the seventh, where he’d dismount and mount the seventh chariot.

mn24:14.11.eng: The seventh chariot at the ready would bring him to the gate of the royal compound of Sāketa.

mn24:14.12.pli: Tamenaṃ antepuradvāragataṃ samānaṃ mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
mn24:14.12.eng: And when he was at the gate, friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would ask him:

mn24:14.13.pli: ‘iminā tvaṃ, mahārāja, rathavinītena sāvatthiyā sāketaṃ anuppatto antepuradvāran’ti?
mn24:14.13.eng: ‘Great king, did you come to Sāketa from Sāvatthī by this chariot at the ready?’

mn24:14.14.pli: Kathaṃ byākaramāno nu kho, āvuso, rājā pasenadi kosalo sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti?
mn24:14.14.eng: If asked this, how should King Pasenadi rightly reply?”

mn24:14.15.pli: “Evaṃ byākaramāno kho, āvuso, rājā pasenadi kosalo sammā byākaramāno byākareyya:

mn24:14.16.pli: ‘idha me sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasantassa sākete kiñcideva accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ uppajji.
mn24:14.16.eng: ‘Well, while staying in Sāvatthī, I had some urgent business come up in Sāketa.

mn24:14.17.pli: Tassa me antarā ca sāvatthiṃ antarā ca sāketaṃ satta rathavinītāni upaṭṭhapesuṃ.
mn24:14.17.eng: Now, between Sāvatthī and Sāketa seven chariots were stationed at the ready for me.

mn24:14.18.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ sāvatthiyā nikkhamitvā antepuradvārā paṭhamaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruhiṃ.
mn24:14.18.eng: Then, exiting Sāvatthī, I mounted the first chariot at the ready by the gate of the royal compound.

mn24:14.19.pli: Paṭhamena rathavinītena dutiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇiṃ, paṭhamaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjiṃ dutiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruhiṃ.
mn24:14.19.eng: The first chariot at the ready brought me to the second, where I dismounted and mounted the second chariot. …

mn24:14.20.pli: Dutiyena rathavinītena tatiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇiṃ, dutiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjiṃ, tatiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruhiṃ.
mn24:14.20.eng: The second chariot brought me to the third …

mn24:14.21.pli: Tatiyena rathavinītena catutthaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇiṃ, tatiyaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjiṃ, catutthaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruhiṃ.

mn24:14.22.pli: Catutthena rathavinītena pañcamaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇiṃ, catutthaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjiṃ, pañcamaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruhiṃ.

mn24:14.23.pli: Pañcamena rathavinītena chaṭṭhaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇiṃ, pañcamaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjiṃ, chaṭṭhaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruhiṃ.

mn24:14.24.pli: Chaṭṭhena rathavinītena sattamaṃ rathavinītaṃ pāpuṇiṃ, chaṭṭhaṃ rathavinītaṃ vissajjiṃ, sattamaṃ rathavinītaṃ abhiruhiṃ.
mn24:14.24.eng: The sixth chariot at the ready brought me to the seventh, where I dismounted and mounted the seventh chariot.

mn24:14.25.eng: The seventh chariot at the ready brought me to the gate of the royal compound of Sāketa.’

mn24:14.26.pli: Evaṃ byākaramāno kho, āvuso, rājā pasenadi kosalo sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti.
mn24:14.26.eng: That’s how King Pasenadi should rightly reply.”

mn24:15.1.pli: “Evameva kho, āvuso, sīlavisuddhi yāvadeva cittavisuddhatthā, cittavisuddhi yāvadeva diṭṭhivisuddhatthā, diṭṭhivisuddhi yāvadeva kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhatthā, kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi yāvadeva maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhatthā, maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhi yāvadeva paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhatthā, paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhi yāvadeva ñāṇadassanavisuddhatthā, ñāṇadassanavisuddhi yāvadeva anupādāparinibbānatthā.
mn24:15.1.eng: “In the same way, reverend, purification of ethics is only for the sake of purification of mind. Purification of mind is only for the sake of purification of view. Purification of view is only for the sake of purification by traversing doubt. Purification by traversing doubt is only for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path. Purification of knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path is only for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision of the practice. Purification of knowledge and vision of the practice is only for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision. Purification of knowledge and vision is only for the sake of extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.

mn24:15.2.pli: Anupādāparinibbānatthaṃ kho, āvuso, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti.
mn24:15.2.eng: The spiritual life is lived under the Buddha for the sake of complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.”

mn24:16.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn24:16.1.eng: When he said this, Sāriputta said to Puṇṇa,

mn24:16.2.eng: “What is the venerable’s name? And how are you known among your spiritual companions?”

mn24:16.4.pli: mantāṇiputtoti ca pana maṃ sabrahmacārī jānantī”ti.
mn24:16.4.eng: And I am known as ‘son of Mantāṇī’ among my spiritual companions.”

mn24:16.6.pli: Yathā taṃ sutavatā sāvakena sammadeva satthusāsanaṃ ājānantena, evameva āyasmatā puṇṇena mantāṇiputtena gambhīrā gambhīrapañhā anumassa anumassa byākatā.
mn24:16.6.eng: Venerable Puṇṇa son of Mantāṇī has answered each deep question point by point, as a learned disciple who rightly understands the teacher’s instructions.

mn24:16.7.eng: It is fortunate for his spiritual companions, so very fortunate,

mn24:16.8.pli: ye āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ labhanti dassanāya, labhanti payirūpāsanāya.
mn24:16.8.eng: that they get to see Venerable Puṇṇa son of Mantāṇī and pay homage to him.

mn24:16.9.pli: Celaṇḍukena cepi sabrahmacārī āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ muddhanā pariharantā labheyyuṃ dassanāya, labheyyuṃ payirūpāsanāya, tesampi lābhā tesampi suladdhaṃ, amhākampi lābhā amhākampi suladdhaṃ, ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ puṇṇaṃ mantāṇiputtaṃ labhāma dassanāya, labhāma payirūpāsanāyā”ti.
mn24:16.9.eng: Even if they only got to see him and pay respects to him by carrying him around on their heads on a roll of cloth, it would still be very fortunate for them! And it’s fortunate for me, so very fortunate, that I get to see the venerable and pay homage to him.”
mn24:16.9.comm: “A roll of cloth” (celaṇḍuka) is a unique term, and these are unique words of praise.

mn24:17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā puṇṇo mantāṇiputto āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn24:17.1.eng: When he said this, Puṇṇa said to Sāriputta,

mn24:17.2.pli: “ko nāmo āyasmā, kathañca panāyasmantaṃ sabrahmacārī jānantī”ti?
mn24:17.2.eng: “What is the venerable’s name? And how are you known among your spiritual companions?”

mn24:17.4.pli: sāriputtoti ca pana maṃ sabrahmacārī jānantī”ti.
mn24:17.4.eng: And I am known as Sāriputta among my spiritual companions.”

mn24:17.5.pli: “Satthukappena vata kira, bho, sāvakena saddhiṃ mantayamānā na jānimha:
mn24:17.5.eng: “Goodness! I had no idea I was consulting with the Venerable Sāriputta, the disciple who is fit to be compared with the Teacher himself!
mn24:17.5.comm: “Fit to be compared with the Teacher” (satthukappa) is another term that is unique in early Pali.

mn24:17.7.pli: Sace hi mayaṃ jāneyyāma ‘āyasmā sāriputto’ti, ettakampi no nappaṭibhāseyya.
mn24:17.7.eng: If I’d known, I would not have said so much.

mn24:17.9.pli: Yathā taṃ sutavatā sāvakena sammadeva satthusāsanaṃ ājānantena, evameva āyasmatā sāriputtena gambhīrā gambhīrapañhā anumassa anumassa pucchitā.
mn24:17.9.eng: Venerable Sāriputta has asked each deep question point by point, as a learned disciple who rightly understands the teacher’s instructions.
mn24:17.9.comm: “Point by point” (anumassa anumassa), found several times above, is yet another phrasing unique to this sutta. | This sutta has several features that, taken together, indicate that it is later than the bulk of the four nikāyas: many unique phrases; the hints that Puṇṇa is from a distant land; and most of all, the doctrine. The text here takes the set of four purifications at AN 4.194 and expands “view” into five to make the seven of the current sutta. Now, AN 4.194 lacks any mention of where the Buddha was at the time and hence was likely taught by Ānanda after the Buddha’s death. Then the set is expanded to nine (plus wisdom and freedom) at DN 34:2.2.6, one of the latest suttas in the nikāyas. Most importantly, the five items pertaining to stream-entry are presented here as a linear sequence, anticipating the detailed analysis of stages of insight in later Theravada. Thus not only are the associated suttas late, this sutta is developed further than them.

mn24:17.10.eng: It is fortunate for his spiritual companions, so very fortunate,

mn24:17.11.pli: ye āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ labhanti dassanāya, labhanti payirūpāsanāya.
mn24:17.11.eng: that they get to see Venerable Sāriputta and pay homage to him.

mn24:17.12.pli: Celaṇḍukena cepi sabrahmacārī āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ muddhanā pariharantā labheyyuṃ dassanāya, labheyyuṃ payirūpāsanāya, tesampi lābhā tesampi suladdhaṃ, amhākampi lābhā amhākampi suladdhaṃ, ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ labhāma dassanāya, labhāma payirūpāsanāyā”ti.
mn24:17.12.eng: Even if they only got to see him and pay respects to him by carrying him around on their heads on a roll of cloth, it would still be very fortunate for them! And it’s fortunate for me, so very fortunate, that I get to see the venerable and pay homage to him.”

mn24:17.13.pli: Itiha te ubhopi mahānāgā aññamaññassa subhāsitaṃ samanumodiṃsūti.
mn24:17.13.eng: And so these two spiritual giants agreed with each others’ fine words.
